Metadata: Correlated non-Gaussian models in offshore structural reliability
"Proceedings of the Fifth International Conference on Structural Safety and Reliability," San Francisco, California, 1989.

Reliability theory has found widespread application in the analysis and design of offshore structures. A major challenge in such applications is to determine a minimally sufficient probabilistic description of the governing load and response variables. While these variables are often assigned Gaussian distributions, non-Gaussian aspects may be induced by nonlinearities in wave kinematics, fluid drag forces or structural behavior. Here non-Gaussian models are constructed from limited, easily estimated statistics: correlation coefficients and either marginal distributions or moments. Applications shown include moment-based models of correlated long-term environmental variables, such as significant wave height and average period, and of short-term wave elevations and forces. These short- and long-term models are also combined to predicts extreme wave levels.
